ack.title: ACKNOWLEDGMENTS
ack.p: We thank Michael Koomey and Bente Borud for provision of reagents for assessing pgl phenotypes and for performing Western blotting for confirmation of pgl expression states. We thank Darryl Hill for provision of an anti-Opa antiserum. We thank multiple undergraduate and master students for contributions to experimental data sets. We thank the student volunteers who provided samples through the underpinning carriage study in 2008 to 2009 at the University of Nottingham, UK.

This work was supported by a Medical Research Council grant MR/M020193/1 to C.D.B., Higher Commission for Educational Development in Iraq (PhD funding) for A.A.A.-R. and M.A.R.M.A.-M., and Wellcome Trust grants 104992/Z/14/Z and 087622/Z/08/A to M.C.J.M. The funders had no role in study design, data collection and interpretation, or the decision to submit the work for publication.
This study made use of the Neisseria PubMLST website ( https://pubmlst.org/neisseria/) hosted by the University of Oxford and developed with funding from the Wellcome Trust and European Union ( 55).

The work was conceived and planned by C.D.B., L.R.G., N.J.O., D.P.J.T., and M.C.J.M. Genome sequencing was facilitated by O.B.H. and M.C.J.M. Experimental work was performed by L.R.G. and A.A.A.-R. Bioinformatics was performed by M.A.R.M.A.-M., O.B.H., M.B., L.R.G., and C.D.B. The manuscript was written by C.D.B. and L.R.G. All authors commented on the final draft.
C.D.B. reports funding from or interactions with GlaxoSmithKline, Sanofi Pasteur MSD, Pfizer, and Roche, outside the submitted work. All other authors declare no competing interests.
